A ;j_sh; is a special sentence, which consists of two parts:

1. A ;shart;.
2. A ;jawab_shart;.

Here is an example of a ;j_sh;:

(@) [If you honor me, I will honor you.]{.trans}

@fig-cst_eng_ex1 shows the two parts of ;j_sh;.

::: {#fig-cst_eng_ex1 .test-class}

<!--

Another common ;adat_shart; is "[when]{.trans}".

-->
Here is another example of a ;j_sh;:

(@) [When the sun rises, the day begins.]{.trans}

Typically,
the statement in ;jawab_shart;
is caused by the realization of the statement in the ;shart;.
So, in example () above,
my honoring you is caused by,
and dependent on,
your honoring me.
And in example (), the day's beginning is caused by the rising of the sun.

However, the statement in the ;jawab_shart; need not always be caused by the condition.^[[@nahw_wafi@ 4/422 footnote 1](https://shamela.ws/book/10641/2354)]
For example:

(@) [If you honor me, then I already honored you yesterday.]{.trans}

In example (), the ;jawab_shart;
[then I already honored you yesterday]{.trans}
is not caused by the realization of the condition
[if you honor me]{.trans}.
Rather it is only a response that completes the sentence.

#;j_sh;s in Arabic are introduced by _;adat_shart;s_ like:
;in; [if]{.trans},
;law; [if]{.trans},
;idha; [when]{.trans},
;man; [who(ever)]{.trans},
;maa; [what(ever)]{.trans},
etc.

Amongst these ;adat_shart;s,
;in; is considered the most basic ;adat_shart;.^[[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 5/106](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/2044)]
We will study 
it
first.

## The ;j_sh; with ;in;

<!--
is used to form the _;arch;_ ;j_sh;.
Other types of ;j_sh; are formed based on the
model of
;arch; ;j_sh; with ;in;.
-->

### The ;arch; ;j_sh; with ;in;

In its ;arch; form,
the ;j_sh; consists of two parts:

1. a ;shart;, consisting of:
   a. the ;adat_shart; ;in;, and 
   b. a ;j_f3l; consisting of (at least):
      * a ;0state; ;mudarie; verb (the *;fi3l_shart;*) and
      * its ;faa3il;
2. a ;jawab_shart;, consisting of a ;j_f3l; with (at least):
      * a ;0state; ;mudarie; verb (the *;fi3l_jawab_shart;*) and
      * its ;faa3il;

<!--
In this ;arch; form of the ;j_sh;,
-->
The conditional particle ;in; directly
governs the ;fi3l_shart; and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart; in the ;0state;.^[@peled_cst@ 3-4 citing @sibawayhi@]
Here is an example of an ;arch; ;j_sh;

(@) [إِنْ يَأْتِ زَيْدٌ يُكْرِمْهُ عَمْرٌو]{.ar}  
    [If Zayd comes, ;3amr; will honor him.]{.trans}  

<!--
In example () above,

  i. The conditional particle is ;in;,
 ii. the ;shart; is [تَأْتِنِي]{.ar}, and
iii. the ;jawab_shart; is [آتِكَ]{.ar}.
-->

the ;fi3l_shart;
[يَأْتِ]{.ar}
and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;
[يُكْرِمْ]{.ar}
(directly)
in the ;0state;.

Here are some more examples of the archetypal conditional sentence:

(@) [إِنْ تَأْتِنِي آتِكَ]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 3/63](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/916)]{.citex}  
    [If you come to me, I will come to you.]{.trans}

(@) [وإن تضرب أضرب]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 3/63](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/916)]{.citex}  
    [If you beat, I will beat.]{.trans}

### The ;madi; verb with ;in;

A ;madi; verb can be used instead of one or both of the ;0state; verbs in a ;j_sh;.
So, for example, instead of saying:

(@) [إِنْ تَأْتِنِي آتِكَ]{.ar}

we can say, any one of:

(@) [إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِي أَتَيْتُكَ]{.ar}

(@) [إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِي آتِكَ]{.ar}

(@) [إِنْ تَأْتِنِي أَتَيْتُكَ]{.ar}

In general, all four options will have more-or-less the same meaning:
[If you come to me, I will come to you.]{.trans}.
In section\ (ref) below,
we will discuss the tense indicated by ;j_sh;s in more detail.
But for now we can consider the ;madi; verb in a ;j_sh; to lose its past tense meaning.

Of the four options in examples () through (),
the combination in
example ()
[إِنْ تَأْتِنِي أَتَيْتُكَ]{.ar},
where the
;fi3l_shart;
is a
;0state; ;mudarie; verb,
and the
;fi3l_jawab_shart;
is a
;madi; verb
is the least commonly
found
in actual usage.
This is because when the
;fi3l_shart;
is
;0state; ;mudarie; verb,
it prefers
another
;0state; ;mudarie; verb
after it as the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;.
Nevertheless,
this is occasionally found,
as we show in example () below.


With regards to the government of the ;j_sh;s in examples () through (),
The ;adat_shart; ;in; will continue to govern
the ;fi3l_shart; and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart; in the ;0state; directly,
regardless of whether the verbs are ;mudarie; verbs or ;madi; verbs.
For ;madi; verbs, they will be in the ;0state; ;mahall;ly.^[wafi]

In other words, ;in; does not govern the ;j_f3l;s
[أَتَيْتَنِي]{.ar}
and
[أَتَيْتُكَ]{.ar} in the ;mahall; ;0state;.
Rather,
the ;madi; verb
[أَتَى]{.ar}
is itself governed in the ;mahall; ;0state;.^[haazimi]

@fig-in_ataytani_ataytuka depicts the government of example ().

::: {#fig-in_ataytani_ataytuka .test-class}

### Negating the ;shart; or ;jawab_shart;

When either of
the ;fi3l_shart; or the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;
are to be negated,
then we have two options:

 i. negate the ;0state; ;mudarie; verb with [لَا]{.ar}
ii. negate the ;0state; ;mudarie; verb with [لَمْ]{.ar}

The ;madi; verb
(with the negater [مَا]{.ar})
and the ;astate; ;mudarie; verb (with [لَنْ]{.ar})
are not used when negating
the ;fi3l_shart; or the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;.^[@nahw_wafi@]
(They can however be used when negating a verb
which is not directly
the ;fi3l_shart; or the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;, as we will see in section\ (ref), ;ia;.)

Option (i) with [لَا]{.ar} is possibly the more original,^[@peled_cst@ 17]
but it is rarer in usage.
Here are some examples:

(@) [إِلَّا تَفۡعَلُوهُ تَكُن فِتۡنَةࣱ فِی ٱلۡأَرۡضِ وَفَسَادࣱ كَبِیرࣱ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/8/73@ cited by @reckendorf_syntax@ 487]{.citex}  
    [If you do not do so [i.e., ally yourselves with other believers], there will be fitnah [i.e., disbelief and oppression] on earth and great corruption.]{.trans}  

(@) [إِنْ تَدْفِنُوا الدَّاءَ **لَا نُخْفِهِ**]{.ar}
    [@reckendorf_syntax@ 487]{.citex}  

(@) [**إِنْ لَا تَكُنْ** هِنْدٌ بَكَتْهُ فَقَدْ بَكَتْ عَلَيْهِ الثُّرَيَّا]{.ar}
    [@reckendorf_syntax@ 487]{.citex}  
    [If Hind did not weep [for] him, then the Pleiades have wept over him]{.trans}  
    (The ;jawab_shart; in this example begins with [فَ]{.ar}. We will discuss this in section\ (ref) below.)  

(@) [اللهُمّ إنْ تَظْهَرْ عَلَيّ هَذِهِ الْعِصَابَةُ يَظْهَرْ الشّرْكُ، **وَلَا يَقُمْ** لَك دِين]{.ar}
    [[@maghazi_waqidi@ 1/67](https://shamela.ws/book/23680/108) cited by @peled_cst@ 15]{.citex}  

The particle [لَا]{.ar}
will not affect the government of
the ;fi3l_shart; or the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;.
The conditional particle ;in; will continue to govern these verbs directly in the ;0state;.

Option (ii) using [لَمْ]{.ar}
(instead of [لَا]{.ar})
is by far the more common technique to negate
the ;fi3l_shart; and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;.

When
;lam; is used to negate
the ;fi3l_shart; or the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;,
the verb retains its future meaning.

Here are some examples of
the ;fi3l_shart; and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;,
negated with ;lam;:


(@) [إن **أتيتني** لم آتك]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 3/91](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/944)]{.citex}  

(@) [إن **لم تأتني** أجزك]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 3/68](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/921)]{.citex}  

(@) [إن **لم تأتني لم آتك**]{.ar}

(@) [إِنِ افْتَرَقْتُمْ **لَمْ تَجْتَمِعُوا** أَبَدًا]{.ar}
    [[@tarikh_tabari@ 4/24](https://shamela.ws/book/9783/1915) cited by @reckendorf_syntax@ 485]{.citex}  

The grammarians differed regarding
the government of the 
the ;fi3l_shart; and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;,
when negated with ;lam;.^[@nahw_wafi@]
Some grammarians are of the opinion that
;lam; directly governs the ;0state; mudarie verb
while ;in; governs the ;j_f3l;s which contain the ;mudarie; verb.

@fig-gov_in_lam_a for example ().

Other grammarians were of the opinion that ;in; would continue to govern
the ;fi3l_shart; and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart; directly,
and that ;lam; has no governing effect in this case.
This is depicted in
@fig-gov_in_lam_b for the same example ().

### The ;jawab_shart; that begins with [فَ]{.ar}

So far, we have studied

### The inverted conditional sentence

[@nahw_wafi@ 4/450-451 (footnote); @peled_cst@ 139--140; @ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 5/118]

Oftentimes,
we come across an _inverted_ conditional sentence,
where what seems to be the ;jawab_shart; comes before the ;shart;.
For example:

(@) [آتِيكَ إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 5/118](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/2056)]{.citex}  
    [I will come to you if you come to me.]{.trans}  

In example () above, it would seem that
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}
is the ;jawab_shart;
and
[إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى]{.ar}
is the ;shart;.

But actually,
the mainstream view amongst the grammarians is that
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}
cannot be a ;jawab_shart; because the
;jawab_shart; is not allowed to precede the ;shart;.

This view is supported by the fact that the
verb in
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}
is in the ;ustate;.
If it were a ;fi3l_jawab_shart; then it would be in the ;0state;, thus:
[آتِكَ]{.ar}.
But
a ;0state; ;mudarie; verb in the beginning of sentence,
followed by a ;shart; is not a correctly formed sentence.
So we cannot say, for example:

(@) ;x; [آتِكَ إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 5/118](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/2056)]{.citex}  

The way the grammarians solve
the analysis of example () is
by considering
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}
an independent sentence
that is
;isnaad_comp;.
[إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى]{.ar}
is then considered to be a ;shart;.
Its
;jawab_shart;
[[آتِكَ]]{.ar}
is ;qaddared;
after it.
The ;qaddared; ;jawab_shart;
is deleted in surface speech
and its meaning is indicated by the preceding independent sentence
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}.

The complete sentence with the ;taqdir; is:

(@) [آتِيكَ إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى [آتِكَ]]{.ar}

<!--
The ;taqdir; of the deleted ;jawab_shart; is 
[آتِكَ]{.ar}.
This rendition of the ;taqdir; is suggested by the preceding independent sentence
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}.
-->

But how is the ;j_sh;
[إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى [آتِكَ]]{.ar}
connected
to the preceding independent sentence
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}?
One opinion
is that the ;j_sh;
[إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِى [آتِكَ]]{.ar}
can be considered to be
attached to (i.e. governed by) the verb in
[آتِيكَ]{.ar}
in much the same way as an ;dharf; or preposition would be.
For example, in:

(@) [آتيك يومَ الجمعة]{.ar}
    [[@ibn_ya3ish_mufassal@ 5/118](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/2056)]{.citex}  
    [I will come to you the day of Friday.]{.trans}

## The ;j_sh; with ;idha;

### The original temporal signification of ;idha;

;idha; "[when]{.trans}"
is a noun which originally has a
temporal (time) signification
rather than a conditional signification.^[@peled_cst@ 24 citing [@sibawayhi@ 3/60](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/913#p1); [@muqtadab@ 2/55-56](https://shamela.ws/book/6965/324#p1)]
For example,

(@) [آتِيكَ إِذَا احْمَرَّ الْبُسْرُ]{.ar}
    [[@sibawayhi@ 3/60](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/913#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I will come to you when the unripe dates redden.]{.trans}

In example () above,
the
;ustate; ;mudarie; verb
[آتِي]{.ar}
signifies its usual imperfect aspect
[I come/will come]{.trans}.
This is because example () is technically not a ;j_sh;.
;idha; signifies
"[when]{.trans}", not as a condition which may or may not occur,
but as an event which is expected to occur.


;idha; is in the ;astate; as a ;dharf_makan;.
It is governed by the verb [آتِي]{.ar}.
;idha; is also a ;mudaf;.
Its (;mahall;) ;mudafil; is
the following ;j_f3l;
[احْمَرَّ الْبُسْرُ]{.ar}.
<!--
A word-for-word translation that indicates this government is:
[I will come to you **at the time of when** the unripe dates redden]{.trans}
-->

;idha; usually indicates a future time.
;idha; is also most commonly followed by a ;madi; verb
in its ;mahall; ;mudafil;,
(like [احْمَرَّ]{.ar} in example () above).
But because of the future signification of ;idha; the ;madi; verb will (usually) give a future meaning:
[when the unripe dates [**will**] redden]{.trans}.

The past tense equivalent of example () above is:

(@) [أَتَيْتُكَ إِذِ احْمَرَّ الْبُسْرُ]{.ar}  
    [I **came** to you when the unripe dates **reddened**.]{.trans}

The ;dharf_makan;
;idh;
usually indicates a past time just like
;idha; usually indicates a future time.

### Conditional signification of ;idha;

Example () above can be transformed into a ;j_sh;.
This is done by taking ;idha; and its ;mahall; ;mudafil;
[احْمَرَّ الْبُسْرُ]{.ar},
and putting them in the front of
the sentence,
<!--
the ;j_f3l;
[آتِيكَ]{.ar},
-->
thus:

(@) [إِذَا احْمَرَّ الْبُسْرُ أَتَيْتُكَ]{.ar}  
    [When the unripe dates redden, I will come to you.]{.trans}

Note that we have also replaced the ;mudarie; verb
[آتِي]{.ar}
with the ;madi; verb
[أَتَيْتُ]{.ar}.
This is because when ;idha; is a ;adat_shart; in a ;j_sh;,
then, like ;in;,
it requires ;j_f3l;s in both the ;shart; and the ;jawab_shart;.
But whereas ;in; allows both (;0state;) ;mudarie; verbs and ;madi; verbs,
;idha; strongly prefers ;madi; verbs in both clauses.
Because of the typical future signification of ;idha;,
both ;madi; verbs will usually have a future meaning.

Also unlike ;in;, 
even when ;idha; is a ;adat_shart;,
it does not (directly) govern either of the verbs in the ;shart; or the ;jawab_shart;.
Rather, ;idha; governs entire ;j_f3l; in the ;shart; in an ;idaafah;.
And ;idha; itself is governed by the verb in the ;jawab_shart;.^[Some grammarians disagreed. Give Abu Hayyan's opinion.]

## Tense

<!--
So far we have deferred a detailed discussion
of the tense indicated by the ;shart; and the ;jawab_shart;.
In this section, we will try to do justice to the topic, ;ia;.
-->

Earlier we had summarily stated that
the tense signified
in ;j_sh;s is generally the future tense,
regardless of what form of verb
(for example: ;0state; or ;madi;)
is used.

However, there are instances of
of a ;j_sh; having been analyzed to have a past significance.
For example:

(@) [قَالُوۤا۟ إِن یَسۡرِقۡ فَقَدۡ سَرَقَ أَخࣱ لَّهُۥ مِن قَبۡلُۚ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/12/77@]{.citex}  
    [They said, "If he steals - a brother of his has stolen before."]{.trans}

The grammarian Ibn Malik interprets the ;shart; in this ;ayah; as having a past significance.^[shawahid_tawdeeh 231]
Similarly, The grammarian and mufassir Abu Hayyan says that the meaning of
is [إن كان قد سرق]{.ar}
[If he had stolen]{.trans}.^[bahr]

Consider also the following ;ayah;:

(@) [وَإِذَا رَأَوۡا۟ تِجَـٰرَةً أَوۡ لَهۡوًا ٱنفَضُّوۤا۟ إِلَیۡهَا وَتَرَكُوكَ قَاۤىِٕمࣰاۚ]{.quran}
    [@https://quran.com/62/11@]{.citex}  
    [But [on one occasion] when they saw a transaction or a diversion, [O Muḥammad], they rushed to it and left you standing.]{.trans}  

So how do we relate the forms of the
;fi3l_shart;
and the ;fi3l_jawab_shart;
to the tense signified by the ;j_sh;?
We will attempt to explain this below:

As you know,
the following positive verb forms are used in ;j_sh;s:

1. The ;0state; ;mudarie; verb

   (@) [إِنْ **تَأْتِنِي أُكْرِمْكَ**]{.ar}  

2. The ;madi; verb. For example:

   (@) [إِنْ **أَتَيْتَنِي أَكْرَمْتُكَ**]{.ar}  

   (@) [إِذَا  **أَتَيْتَنِي أَكْرَمْتُكَ**]{.ar}  

3. The ;ustate; ;mudarie; verb.

   (@) [إِنْ أَتَيْتَنِي **أُكْرِمُكَ**]{.ar}  

   (@) [إِذَا **تَأْتِينِي أُكْرِمُكَ**]{.ar}  

Not all combinations of the verb forms
are shown in examples () through () above.
Other combinations,
and their relative frequencies of usage,
have been discussed
in sections\ (refs) above.

The question is,
when is one verb form chosen over another,
and what difference in meaning would it signify?

First, we would like to state
that in many cases the verb forms,
when permissible,
are often interchangeable.
And the nuances in meaning that we will attempt to explain below
are more
connotations and trends
rather than hard and fast rules.
Needless to say, they are also based on our subjective reasoning,
and therefore liable to critique.

We will begin by first listing the essential significances of each of the above verb forms
independent of ;j_sh;s.
We will then explain how those essential significances can carry over to within ;j_sh;s.

The essential signification of the
;madi; verb form
is that an action
has reached a completed state.
So for example, if we say
[أَتَيْتَنِي]{.ar},
then the ;madi; verb form signifies that
your action of coming to me has been completed.

The essential signification of the
;ustate; ;mudarie; verb form
is that
an action
is either on-going,
or that it will occur in the future.
So for example, if we say
[تَأْتِينِي]{.ar},
then the ;ustate; ;mudarie; verb form signifies that
your action of coming to me is either on-going,
or that it will occur in the future.

The essential signification of the positive ;0state; ;mudarie; verb
is that the speaker
considers an action
to be potentially possible.^[3aarif al-deen 49]
So for example, if we say
[تَأْتِنِي]{.ar},
then the ;0state; ;mudarie; verb form indicates
that your coming to me is a potential possibility.

When these verb forms are used in the ;shart;
or the ;jawab_shart;,
then their essential significations (above)
can continue to have influence on the meaning.

So,
if we use a ;madi; verb
as a ;fi3l_shart; or a ;fi3l_jawab_shart;
then it will indicate a completed action.
The tense is determined by when the scenario of ;shart; will occur.

If, for example, the scenario of the condition occurred in the past,
then the ;j_sh; will have a past tense meaning.
For example:

(@) [توقعت إتيانك إياي أمس.  وإِنْ أَتَيْتَنِي أَكْرَمْتُكَ]{.ar}  
    [I expected your coming to me yesterday.
    And
    if you **had come** to me,
    I **would have honored** you.]{.trans}

And if, the scenario of the condition is expected in the future,
then the ;j_sh; will have a future tense meaning.
For example:


(@) [أَتوقع إتيانك إياي غدا.  وإِنْ أَتَيْتَنِي أَكْرَمْتُكَ]{.ar}  
    [I expect your coming to me tomorrow.
    And
    if you **will have come** to me,
    I **will have honored** you.]{.trans}

Similarly,
if we use a ;0state; ;mudarie; verb
as a ;fi3l_shart; or a ;fi3l_jawab_shart;
then it will indicate a potential action.
The tense is again determined by when the scenario of ;shart; will occur.

If, for example, the scenario of the condition occurred in the past,
then the ;j_sh; will have a past tense meaning.
For example:

<!-- use 3rd person as most general in order not to color from 1st and 2nd person -->

(@) [توقع زيد إتيان عمرو أمس وإِنْ يَأْتِه أَكْرَمَهُ]{.ar}
    [Zayd expected ;3amr;'s coming yesterday. And if he **would have come** to him, he **would have honored** him.]{.trans}

Having said this, the usage of ;0state; ;fi3l_shart; with a past signification is going to be rare.
For a desired past tense, we are more likely to use ;kaana;
with a ;madi; verb in the ;shart;, thus:

(@) [ان كان قد أتاه أكرمه]{.ar}

In most cases, the ;0state;; ;mudarie; verb
will have a future signification.
For example:

(@) [يتوقع زيد إتيان عمرو غدا وإِنْ يَأْتِه يُكْرِمْهُ]{.ar}
    [Zayd expects ;3amr;'s coming tomorrow. And if he **would come** to him, he **would honor** him.]{.trans}
